text:
My dad is from Venezuela,
and my mom's from Mexico.

They actually moved to
the US because my dad
was going to get his MBA.

I think the plan was to
go to school and go back,
but life happened.

Math was always my
strong point and kind

of fell into
electrical engineering.

Chevron was actually the
only internship offer
that I had junior year.

I absolutely love
the experience and so

was grateful to get
to go back full time.

I thought and was
realizing I didn't want
to be an engineer for 40 years.

It would have been kind of
continuous long distance

apart from Sarah,
my wife, and her
trying to manage her career.

And so, an MBA, we thought,
was a great way for both of us
to have a lot more flexibility.

I definitely didn't think that
I was able to get into HBS,

but at least some way that
I could take a chance.
I thought that why not me.

My wife and family
and all that was

going to be a
priority for me, and I

found that Harvard, maybe
contrary to popular belief,

is a great place to work your
career around other things that
are important to you.

Our default is to try to get
dinner together every night
and be together on the weekends.

I'll get home after
school and she's there,

hanging out with
my section mates,
you know, didn't invite me.

I really appreciate
the community here

and how she's been able
to make her own friends.

The first year at HBS
has been unbelievable.

The first time seeing the case
method, I just fell in love.

I could not believe how
engaging that classroom was.

Coming in, I was probably
a little bit nervous
about what I would bring.

I did not know anything
about finance or strategy.

The point is that we are all
contributing to the discussion

because even when you
walk into the room,

see people from all different
backgrounds and countries,

so you right away
see the diversity

and start to understand
how that is going to make
the discussion so unique.

I definitely assumed, before
I got to know anything

about Harvard, that
it was going to be

a place that's not as
diverse, a place that
might be more pretentious.

That I was able to find
people like me, people

who are engineers, people
who are underrepresented

minorities, and really
see how they fit in

and how they added
to the school,

it's been phenomenal how
welcoming people are,

how open people are, how
thoughtful people are.

The people are, unquestionably,
the best thing about HBS.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
